description: UK late-19th century. Borrowed from Yiddish שלימזל‎ (shlimazl, “misfortune”), from Middle High German slim (“crooked”) and Hebrew מַזָּל‎ (mazzāl, “luck”). Cognate with US English schlimazel (“unlucky person”).  Compare German Schlamassel.

entries.meaning: (slang) A state of chaos or confusion.

verbs.description: shemozzle (third-person singular simple present shemozzles, present participle shemozzling, simple past and past participle shemozzled)

entries.meaning: (slang) To scarper; to run away; to flee.
